_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Placerville Hangtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Facility accidental release prevention program involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, policy, and management practices.  It is in compliance with all EPA Prevention Program Requirements.

1. Process Safety Information ? Placerville Hangtown Creek WWTP has developed and maintains written safety information about the chlorination process and the technology of process equipment used.  The operation of this facility adheres to the guidelines of the Chlorine Institute and to the OSHA regulations regarding Process Safety Management.
2. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) ? A PHA has been conducted appropriate to the complexity of the chlorination process that identified, evaluated, and controlled potential hazards using the ?What-If Checklist? and ?Hazard Review Checklists? processes.  These processes include the analysis of hazards due to equipment malfunction and human error.  It describes steps used to detect and monitor releases.  This PHA will be updated every three years and the Placerville WWTP will conduct reviews whenever major changes occur to the process.
3. Operating Procedures ? The WWTP has prepared written procedures that provide clear instructions for the safe operational activities associated with the process.  These procedures are included in the facility operations manual and the Process Safety Management manual.  The manual includes procedures for operation of all phases of the processes, and normal and emergency shutdown of the process.  
4. Employee Training: - All existing and newly assigned employees are trained and tested competent in all operation procedures.  Training documentation is maintained on all applicable employees, refresher training is provided quarterly.
5. Mechanical Integrity ? The WWTP has a preventive maintenance program that insures the mechanical integrity of its chlorination processing equipment, which includes periodic inspection, testing and an annual overhaul of critical processing equipment.
6. Management of Change - WWTP has implemented written procedures to manage changes (except changes in-kind) to process chemical technology, equipment and procedures.  Employees affected by a change in a process are informed of and trained in the change prior to start up of the process or affected part of the process.  Safety information and operation procedures are updated accordingly.
7. Pre-Startup Review ? Written procedures have been developed to allow operators to perform a pre-startup safety review for new and modified chlorination equipment, or where modification to the process is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.
8. Compliance Audits ? Compliance audits will be performed every three years to verify that the procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed.  Water treatment supervisors will perform the audit.  A report will be developed and deficiencies will be corrected.  The two most recent audits will be kept.
9. Incident Investigation ? The Placerville WWTP will investigate any incident, which results or could result in a catastrophic release of chlorine gas.  The investigation will be conducted within 48 hours of the incident.  All key factors will be addressed and recommendations for correction will result.  Affected personnel will review the findings of the investigation.  The report will be kept for 5 years.
10. Employee Participation ? Managers and operators of Placerville WWTP participated in the process hazard analysis.  The PHA has been made available to all affected employees and is kept at the facilities.
11. Hot Work Permit ? A hot work permit process has been developed and implemented for hot work operations conducted on or near the chlorination process.  The permit documents the fire and accident prevention requirements and is implemented prior to beginning any hot work operations.  The permit is kept on file until the completion of any hot work.
12. Contractors ? Contractors working on or near the water treatment plant are required to comply with the regulatory provisions of the OSHA process safety management standard.  A form has been developed to address the following: contractor safety program; informing contractor employees of the hazards on the site; review of the emergency evacuation plans; record contractor meetings of the plans; and require contractors to train their employees on the hazards of the process. 
13. Injury and Illness Prevention Program ? The Placerville WWTP has an active IIPP meeting the requirements of Cal/OSHA Section 3203 that addresses the following;
? Assignment of safety responsibilities
? Programs designed to gain employee involvement such as safety reward and recognition, safety suggestion incentives, and safety rule infraction disciplinary programs.
? An active safety training program
? A hazard identification and corrective action program.
? Incident and Accident investigation process.
? Safety committee made up of union and management personnel.


D.    Emergency Response Program 

Placerville Hangtown Creek WWTP has developed and implemented an emergency response program which is attached to this document. The emergency response program includes interaction and communication with local and state response agencies.  The El Dorado County Environmental Management Department, as part of their business plan program, is notified immediately if there is a hazardous material release.  

The City of Placerville Fire Department will be the incident commander in the case of a chlorine release and will coordinate evacuation procedures in a worst-case scenario.  The California State Office of Emergency Services is notified in a worst-case scenario.  The WWTP?s chlorine or sulfur dioxide supplier is also notified.

A copy of the emergency response plan is maintained in the Placerville Hangtown Creek WWTP Chief Operator?s office.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
City of Placerville Hangtown Creek Waste Water Treatment Plant

Federal Environmental Protection Agency - Risk Management Plan (RMP)

California Accidental Release Plan (Cal/ARP)

INTRODUCTION

The City of Placerville Hangtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant is owned and operated by the City of Placerville, El Dorado County, California.  This plant is located west of Placerville adjacent to the Hangtown Creek.  There are some residences and light commercial occupancies nearby.  The facility processes wastewater from several sources in the City and surrounding communities.    

These EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) Support Documents satisfy the requirements of 40 CFR 68.  

A.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEM

The WWTP accidental release prevention policy involves an approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices.  The facility adheres to all applicable procedures of the federal EPA Risk Management Program (EPA-RMP).  The emergency response policy involves the preparation of response plans, which are tailored to this facility and to the emergency response of the community and local responding agencies.  It is in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program requirements.

The accidental release prevention program (ARP) is in compliance with the federal and State OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) rule and is based upon the following key elements:
?    A high level of training for the facility state certified plant operators.
?    A preventive maintenance program with strict adherence.
?    Use of state of the art process and safety equipment to control and neutralize any accidental release of chemical.
?    The use of an accurate and effective operating procedure written with participation of the operators.
?    Performance of hazard review of equipment and procedures.
?    Assignment of the facility chief operator with overall responsibility of the RMP and Cal/ARP
?    Implementation of an auditing and inspection program under the direction of the wastewater facili

ty chief operator.

These policies and procedures are described in the City of Placerville, Hangtown Creek  Wastewater Treatment Plant Process Safety Management Plan.  This plan, as required by State and local regulatory agencies, also contains information and procedures relating to chlorine and sulfur dioxide processing equipment, handling, leak response and repair procedures, education and safety training.  It contains a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and various report forms.
 

B.  HAZARD ASSESSMENT

This hazard assessment was prepared in compliance with Subpart B of 40 CRF 68.  This is described in sections B1 through B9.

B1.    Applicability

The Placerville Hangtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant handles both chlorine and sulfur dioxide, both EPA-regulated substances, in amounts exceeding the regulatory threshold of 2,500 lbs.  This process of chlorination and de-chlorination is subject to OSHA Process Safety management (PSM) requirements.  This qualified the Plant as a Program 3 process.

B2.       Offsite consequence Analysis Parameters

The offsite consequence analysis parameters are listed below.

(a)    Endpoint

Chlorine - As required by EPA, the chlorine toxic endpoint used is 0.0087 mg/L.   This corresponds to 3 parts per million by volume (PPM), and represents the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) Emergency Response Planning Guideline (ERPG) ? 2, which is defined as ?the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual?s ability to take protective action.?

(b)    Wind speed/atmospheric stability class

As required by EPA, a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (m/s), and an atmospheric stability class F were used for performing the offsite consequence analysis for the worst-case release scenario.

(c)    Ambient temperature/humidity

EPA RMP regulations fo

r the worst-case release analysis assume 25-degree C. (77 degree F.) and 50% humidity for the dispersion analysis of the worst-case scenario.  

(d)    Height of release

The RMP regulations require that, for the worst-case release analysis, the release should be assumed to occur at ground level (0 feet).  Accordingly, the worst-case release analysis was performed at this level.

(e)    Surface roughness

RMP regulations require that either urban or rural topography should be used for performing the air dispersion analysis for the identified release scenarios.  The rural and urban topographical conditions are characterized in the air dispersion models in terms of surface roughness.  The rural condition, defined by EPA as ?no buildings in the immediate area and the terrain is generally flat and unobstructed?, is characterized by a surface roughness of 0.03 meter, whereas the urban condition is characterized by a surface roughness of 1.0 meter.  Urban topographical conditions were chosen due to the trees and buildings in the treatment plant vicinity.

(f)    Dense or neutrally buoyant gases

RMP regulations require that the models used for dispersion analysis should appropriately account for the density of the released gas.  Since the chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas released during the identified accidental release scenarios would be denser-than-air-, the Dense Gas Air Dispersion model was used for performing the air dispersion modeling.

(g)    Temperature of released substance

The facility process temperature coincides with the ambient temperature.  Therefore, the temperature of any released chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas is the same as the ambient temperature.

B3.    Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis

RMP regulations require that a worst-case release scenario analysis be performed in compliance with specified conditions, as detailed below.

(a)    Number of release scenarios

RMP regulations for Program 3 processes require the performance of a consequence analysis for one worst-

case release scenario for each chemical, estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to a toxic endpoint.  The worst-case release scenario selected was the complete release of the following:
?    One-ton chlorine container (2000 lbs.)

(b)    Worst-case release quantity

The one-ton (2000 lbs.) worst-case release quantity selected represents the greatest amount held by a single vessel.  The container is provided with a negative pressure regulator on the manifold and an automatic valve shutoff system that is activated in the event of gas release.  The chlorine building is also provided with an automatic chemical scrubber system to neutralize the contents of the tank.

(c)    Worst case release scenario for toxic gases

According to the RMP regulations, it should be assumed that, for toxic substances that are normally gases at ambient temperature and handled as a gas or as a liquid under pressure, the quantity present in a vessel will be released as a gas over 10 minutes.  The release rate is assumed to be the total quantity divided by 10.  The boiling point temperature for chlorine is ?31 degrees F; thus, chlorine is a gas at ambient temperature.  The worst-case chlorine release rate was therefore estimated at 200 lb. /min.  The potential of any released gasses from the building is very low taking into consideration the construction and containment the building provides and the chemical scrubber system in place.

A summary of all the parameters selected for the dispersion modeling is presented in Table B-1.

The maximum distance to toxic endpoint (3 ppm) reached by chlorine concentrations generated by a 10-minute release of 2,000 lbs. of chlorine is 1.3 miles.  Due to the building enclosure, the maximum distance to toxic endpoint is 0.9 miles.

B4.    Alternative Release Scenario Analysis

RMP regulations require that at least one alternative scenario be identified and analyzed for each regulated toxic substance.  However, if systems are in place showing that no reasonable scenario could lead to offsite consequences, a scenario that has no offsite impacts can be used for the alternative scenario.  The chlorine facility at the Placerville Hangtown Creek Wastewater treatment plant is provided with a fully enclosed structure having an automatically activated chemical scrubbing system for the released chlorine.

(a)    Scenarios to Consider

RMP regulations require that a scenario, which is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario, be selected as the alternative release.  The scenario selected involves the rupture of the flexible connections (pigtails) connected to the one-ton containers.  

Upon release of the chlorine gas from the line, the leak detection system (with battery and emergency power backup) would activate an emergency alarm the chemical scrubber system.  The chemical scrubber system has the capability to neutralize the contents of the faulty chlorine tank.

(b)    Parameters to be Applied

None Applicable with this scenario.


(c)    Consideration of Mitigation

The active mitigation system considered is the actuation of a chlorine detector connected to an automatic emergency call system.  This system will allow for immediate notification of chlorine leaks to facility operators who will then initiate the emergency respons

e plan.  Any chlorine released inside the building will be neutralized by the chemical scrubber system.  Emergency responders have been trained and are prepared to enter the building using chemical protective suits (level 1) and apply the necessary equipment to stop or contain a leak in the cylinder or feed line.  The amount of chlorine released will be less than the EPA reportable amount of 10 pounds.  

(d)    Factors in Selecting Scenarios

The rationale for selection of this scenario, which is more likely to occur than the EPA worst-case release discussed in Section B3, is based on performance of a hazard review.

B5.    Offsite Impacts ? Population

EPA RMP regulations require the determination of the potentially affected residential population within a circle with its center at the point of the release and a radius determined by the distance to the endpoint estimated to two significant digits.  

Considering the worst-case release scenario, it is estimated that approximately 1,774 people live within the endpoint circle and 200 people within the plume footprint.

Due to the active mitigation systems in place, we believe there is no reasonable alternative release scenario that could lead to offsite consequence to population.

B6.    Offsite Impacts ? Environment

Environmental receptors to be identified include natural areas such as national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, or areas, and Federal wilderness areas.  

Considering the worst-case release scenario, there are no environmental receptors within distance to endpoint.

Due to the active mitigation system in place, we believe there is no reasonable alternative release scenario that could lead to offsite consequence to environment.







B7.    Review and Update

(a)    The Placerville Hangtown Creek WWTP Chief Operator will review and update the offsite consequence analysis at least once every five years.
(b)    If changes in processes, quantities stored

or handled, or any other aspect of the facility might reasonably be expected to increase or decrease the distance to the endpoint by a factor of two or more, the WWTP Chief Operator will complete a revised analysis within six months of the change and submit a revised risk management plan.

B8.    Documentation

The required records for the offsite consequence analyses are provided above in Sections B2 through B6.

B9.    Five-Year Accident History

No accidental chlorine releases have occurred at this facility.  Accident definitions and accident investigation procedures are provided in the Process Safety Management Plan.
